results.title: Edge of the outback
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and Stefan Sargent
results.brief_description: A picture of the life in the region of Longreach, Queensland, at the time of the annual Agricultural Show in a drought season. Without explicit commentary we candidly observe a grazier and his family over several days while they go about their family, business and social life

results.title: Edge of the deep
results.creator_credit: Boolari Films, Peter Bruce and David Corke
results.brief_description: The film illustrates the way of life on the sea shore. Many birds such as gulls, pelicans, swans and cormorants are shown and their adaptations to the tidal pattern explained. Migratory and breeding habits of other species are discussed. This poetic film of bird life is centred round two derelict barges which locate the scene and establish the continuity of the movements of the tide.

results.title: Edge of darkness. Pt. 1
results.brief_description: Into the Shadows - His investigation into his daughter’s murder reveals to Ronald Craven her involvement in nuclear power, politics, terrorism and death. Despite the agonies of his grief, Cravan finds himself drawn into Emma’s secret world. Rated: M

results.creator_credit: American Mutoscope and Biograph Company and D.W. Griffith

results.title: Edgar Allan Poe
results.creator_credit: Arthur G. Evans and Stuart O'Brien
results.brief_description: One of the first American writers of international importance, Poe became a widely read master of the short story, yet his life seemed a fabric of despair, failure, frustration and poverty. This film presents a sympathetic account of Poe’s life and work narrated by Lorne Greene. To conclude there is a reading of Poe’s famous poem, ANNABEL LEE

results.title: Eden et Apres = Eden and After
results.brief_description:
A group of students hang out at the Eden cafe, swapping tale of adventures and fantasies. The sudden arrival of a mysterious stranger upsets their collective daydreaming and starts a cycle of ‘surreal’ events.

Credits: Producer, Maurice Urbain ; director, Alain Robbe-Grillet ; writer, Alain Robbe-Grillet ; photography, Igor Luther ; music, Michel Fano.
Cast: Catherine Jourdan, Pierre Zimmer, Lorraine Rainer, Sylvain Corthay, Richard Leduc.

results.title: Eden's Lost
results.creator_credit: Central Independent Television (UK), ABC-TV (Australia), Margaret Fink and Neil Armfield
results.brief_description: Based on a novel by Sumner Locke Elliott, this is the story of Angus Weekes and the unusual family of Eve St. James. Taken in by Eve after the death of his guardian, Angus cannot resist becoming involved in the ultimately tragic patterns of their lives. This is ‘art-television’ in the BBC tradition of literary adaptation. Like the novel it is structured in three parts. ‘Angus’ (episode I) is the most Gothic and melodramatic in structure and tone; ‘Bea’ (episode II) is the most naturalistic and ‘Eve’ (episode III) is the most concentrated and formally rigorous. Cast includes Julia Blake, Arthur Dignam, Linda Cropper, Victoria Longley and Bruce Hughes.

results.title: Eden
results.brief_description: Eden is an old growth forest in the Mount Kosciusko region of N.S.W.’s South-East that is still being logged today. Benjamin Cruse, the narator and member of Eden Land Council, tells of the efforts being made to save the remainder of the forest from total devastation. An Aboriginal man whose ancestors belonged to the region, Cruz describes the logging companies attitude towards the land as being connected and the same to the attitude of the ‘settlers’ toward indigenous people. The Aboriginal relationship with the land in Australia is described as being the ‘original human relationship’, the land is where the spirit is born and returns to upon death.
